column4: Hi. I've just bought an used Dell monitor and plugged it to my PC. It works fine, but instead of its native 1280x1024 gnome-display-properties manager shows something strange, like 1152x864 or 1360x768. It seems that everyone has problems with Dell monitors. I succeeded making it use 1280x1024 by typing xrandr  --newmode "1280x1024_60.00"  109.00  1280 1368 1496 1712  1024 1027 1034 1063 -hsync +vsync; xrandr --addmode VGA "1280x1024_60.00"; xrandr --o
utput VGA --mode "1280x1024_60.00". But system forgets this mode after reboot. How to make it remember it, and remove those strange modes?
Doesn't work, at least in Ubuntu.
ikanobory, yes, it should, but doesn't. It was the first thing I tried.
ikanobory, It seems that gnome-display-properties somehow override xorg.conf settings.
ikanobory, why do you answer then. Thanks for your participation anyway.

Hi. I've just bought an used Dell monitor and plugged it to my PC. It works fine, but instead of its native 1280x1024 gnome-display-properties manager shows something strange, like 1152x864 or 1360x768. It seems that everyone has problems with Dell monitors. I tried to save those settings in xorg.conf, but to no avail. It seems that gnome-display-properties somehow override xorg.conf settings.I succeeded making it use 1280x1024 by typing xrandr  --newm

ode "1280x1024_60.00"  109.00  1280 1368 1496 1712  1024 1027 1034 1063 -hsync +vsync; xrandr --addmode VGA "1280x1024_60.00"; xrandr --output VGA --mode "1280x1024_60.00". But system forgets this mode after reboot. How to make it remember it, and remove those strange modes?
add a modeline in xorg.conf and edit modes in screen section
to no avail, i tried. A glue is that I can temporary convince xrandr to use a native resolution. Now, how to convince it remember it?
You can just add your modeline to the monitor section
after that you can chose 1280x1024_60 in the screen/display section
